I actually think that they need to change her just a bit yet. Her pool probably clears minions slightly too well.

I'm not an expert in the birdie, but if she really clears too well, I could see them nerf it in the early stages and buff her Q as compensation, so that she uses more Mana to farm. 

Overall, her clear is kinda balanced by the facts that: 

1. It is available only Post-Level 6

2. It is Mana demanding, forcing her to at least build one scaling item.

3. Its range is pretty low. While the area it covers is huge, Anivia has to stay really close to it in order to maintain it, making her vulnerable to flanks and poke.

Overall, if she is problematic, Riot has tons of options to play with.

Yeah, I just fail to see what makes her niche. She's one half tank shredder, but the other half duelist who has montage galore of 1v5'ing. You know whose niche? Kog'maw, Mr. Mobility-less Long Range Shredder. Ivern too. I think there's a question to be asked here however.

What *Is* a niche champion, how do we define that? Is it a champion who you wouldn't pick blind into a team comp? Is it a champion with a identity that is really specific to certain situations? In the case of Vayne, is she niche because she kills tanks better than some ADCs? Almost every ADC can kill tanks, meanwhile Jinx and Twitch can melt entire teams while doing that. Varus and Ashe have massive team utility, and MF and Xayah can set up massive damage on the field. I highly doubt that Vayne's entire character is solely "I kill tanks well". 

My opinion, I don't see Vayne as a niche champion, because I think her duelist side overpowers her tank shredder side, and that's what people are arguably picking her up and playing her as. A duelist, not a tank killer. Like I saw someone say in the %True Damage thread, %percent health damage is target agnostic, you'll always do the same percent health no matter the target, which is the design for Fiora. An ideal damage type for a duelist, since it's equally effective against everyone.

Her duelist capabilities are only now being brought forth as the reason she's overtuned. She was not like this before. Not to say her being a duelist never existed, but it was a much smaller advantage to her kit that was in place so that she could reliably deal with fighters and tanks going in on her since her range was so small compared to the other ADCs. taking a look at how she is now compared to other ADCs who are much more team oriented, she has a much better laning phase and an item build that allows her to duel pretty much anyone.

I believe we're coming to the term niche from different directions.  Allow me to clarify my position.

When I say 'niche' I don't mean 'low pick rate'.

When I say 'niche' I mean a kit is relatively specialized.

Vayne specializes in being a dualist marksmen, SPECIFICALLY a dualist marksmen well adapted at destroying the enemy front-line.  She works best against low to moderately mobile opponents packing high resistance values.  She pays for this by being completely lacking in any sort of range extension or poke.

Basically, she murders juggernauts and fighters and makes things hard for Tanks provided she avoids their opening CC rotation.

That's a very specialized kit.  As opposed to a generalist kit like Jinx who has gameplay that revolves around '5-man rolling murderball'.

Vayne has a very high pick rate because people enjoy her proactive, flashy game play.  And since her pick rate is so high, she's often chosen into team compositions where her niche kit doesn't perform as well.  This drives her win rate down.  Thus, when Vayne has a relatively high win rate, it suggests that she has been over-tuned to the point that she isn't functioning as a niche pick anymore.  She's functioning as a generalist.

And when a niche pick, hard-counter champion is over-tuned to the point that they become a generalist pick they absolutely invalidate the champions that they counter.  Kalista did the same thing when she was a generalist pick.

Are monster champs really that unappealing though? You saw the most recent everyone picks Rek’Sai. People only pick what feels most powerful even if they lose with it. That’s why Yasuo and Lee are always popular. They always feel powerful even if you are shit with them.

They historically hold lower playrates, especially if you look at their overtime playrate. I wouldn't count the people who jump onto whatever bandwagon they think is the strongest, because those people aren't interested in the champion themselves.

But fail to point out that monster champions have always either been A) Poorly Balanced B) Incredibly outdated.

Yorick and Urgot are not even unpopular champions now post updates and the same goes for Rek'sai now that Riot has decided to put effort into balancing her. (Also pre-rework Rek'sai was a consistently popular pick). 

It's also funny considering Yordles are consistenly more UNPOPULAR (Save for Tristana) then a majority of monster champions.

I'd also care to remind you, that both Yorick and Urgot are nowhere close to their original 'monsters' they were before they were reworked. Urgot, much more human than the monstrosity of science we had before. 

You need to keep in mind this: Popularity and Pickrate are two different things. We all know the crowd who jumps onto whatever champion is the strongest, because they want to win. Look at the mains, look at the people playing the champion when they're the weakest. This is the true indicator of how much a champion appeals to them, that they'll play them while they're weak. Because they like the champion, not their strength. 

That's not always the case, especially in terms of extreme gutting, but it's the easiest to see. It's even funnier when you look at Various champions pickrates over time, some almost look abusive, like Syndra's pickrate stemming up to 15% but averagely lying around 3%.

And as a result what the community is left with is a group of champions that have frankly little appeal AND little too relate with.

I think its more than that though. When has Lee Sin, Yasuo type champions not felt good to play? They make plays, they are mobile, they have ok defense, they have ok nuke they have ok ok ok ok. They just excel at everything. 

Meanwhile you have this clunky rock named malphite that hits R and wins or loses. Even one of the more popular monsters Maoaki they reworked multiple times just because he was too powerful and super popular. He is never in a spot where he just feels great to play for very long. 

Personally I just think raw power brings more players than champion looks ever will, and that could very well be an opinion. I would just love it for a monster champion to be flashy like all the other popular champs just so that we can see if it really is the looks or if it is simply game balance. I know I personally care more about how a champion plays than looks.
